description: From Middle English softe, from Old English sōfte, alteration of earlier sēfte (“soft”), from Proto-West Germanic *samftī (“level, even, smooth, soft, gentle”) (compare *sōmiz (“agreeable, fitting”)), from Proto-Indo-European *semptio-, *semtio-, from *sem- (“one, whole”). Cognate with West Frisian sêft (“gentle; soft”), Dutch zacht (“soft”), German Low German sacht (“soft”), German sanft (“soft, yielding”), Old Norse sœmr (“agreeable, fitting”), samr (“same”). More at seem, same.

entries.meaning: Easily giving way under pressure.
examples: My head sank easily into the soft pillow.

entries.meaning: (of cloth or similar material) Smooth and flexible; not rough, rugged, or harsh.
examples: Polish the silver with a soft cloth to avoid scratching.
soft silk; a soft skin

entries.meaning: (of a sound) Quiet.
examples: I could hear the soft rustle of the leaves in the trees.

entries.meaning: Gentle.
examples: There was a soft breeze blowing.

entries.meaning: Expressing gentleness or tenderness; mild; conciliatory; courteous; kind.
examples: soft eyes

entries.meaning: Gentle in action or motion; easy.
Weak in character; impressible.
Requiring little or no effort; easy.
examples: Before that they had been a good deal on the move, trekking about after the white man, who was one of those rolling stones that keep going round after a soft job.

entries.meaning: Not bright or intense.
examples: soft lighting

entries.meaning: Having a slight angle from straight.
examples: At the intersection with two roads going left, take the soft left.
It's important to dance on soft knees to avoid injury.

entries.meaning: (phonetics) Voiced; sonant; lenis.
examples: DH represents the voiced (soft) th of English these clothes.

entries.meaning: (phonetics, rare) Voiceless.
(Slavic phonology) Palatalized.
(slang) Lacking strength or resolve; not tough, wimpy.
examples: When it comes to drinking, he is as soft as they come.

entries.meaning: (of water) Low in dissolved calcium compounds.
examples: You won't need as much soap, as the water here is very soft.

entries.meaning: (UK, colloquial) Foolish.
examples: He made soft fellows stark noddies, and such as were foolish quite mad.

entries.meaning: (physics) Of a ferromagnetic material; a material that becomes essentially non-magnetic when an external magnetic field is removed, a material with a low magnetic coercivity. (compare hard)
(of a person) Physically or emotionally weak.
Incomplete, or temporary; not a full action.
examples: The admin imposed a soft ban on the user.
Messages removed by soft deletion can be recovered if necessary.

entries.meaning: (UK, of a man) Effeminate.
examples: A longing after sensual pleasures is a dissolution of the spirit of a man, and makes it loose, soft, and wandering.

entries.meaning: Agreeable to the senses.
examples: a soft liniment
soft wines

entries.meaning: Not harsh or offensive to the sight; not glaring or jagged; pleasing to the eye.
examples: soft colours
the soft outline of the snow-covered hill

entries.meaning: (photography, of light) Made up of nonparallel rays, tending to wrap around a subject and produce diffuse shadows.
(computing) Emulated with software; not physically real.
examples: Press the red button on the soft phone to hang up.

entries.meaning: (of a drug) Not likely to cause addiction.
(of a drink) Not containing alcohol.
Easy-going, lenient, not strict; permissive.
examples: soft on crime

entries.meaning: (finance) Of a market: having more supply than demand; being a buyer's market.
examples: Antonym: hard

entries.meaning: (of pornography) softcore.
A soft or foolish person; an idiot.
(motorsports) Ellipsis of soft tyre. (A tyre whose compound is softer than mediums, and harder than supersofts.)
(colloquial) A soft sound or part of a sound.
examples: The expander doesn't really make the louds louder and the softs softer in one step  […]

entries.meaning: (gaming, dated) Video game
examples: Sega and third-party licensees are set to release an abundance of softs that range from intense shooters to sports to reflex-testers.

description: From Middle English softe, from Old English sōfte (“softly”), from Proto-West Germanic *samftō (“softly”).

adverbs.description: soft (comparative more soft, superlative most soft)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Softly; without roughness or harshness; gently; quietly.
examples: There was a neat hat-and-umbrella stand, and the stranger's weary feet fell soft on a good, serviceable dark-red drugget, which matched in colour the flock-paper on the walls.
